citations.narrative:
The surfaces of wooden den boxes and raised wooden decking in at least three of the dog enclosures were excessively
worn exposing surfaces which were no longer sealed or able to be readily cleaned and sanitized. Surfaces which are
excessively worn, or contain unsealed, exposed wood may trap harmful organisms and cannot be properly cleaned and
sanitized.
All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily cleaned and
sanitized must be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by 10/19/2023.

An approximately 8 ft. long section of perimeter fence was damaged by a fallen tree due to recent storms. This damaged
section of perimeter fence is currently 2 feet shorter than the required height of 8 feet for the facility’s potentially
dangerous animals. The animal enclosures within this perimeter fence are all closed-top enclosures and there is
appropriate strength hotwire present as an additional safety measure on the perimeter fence. All outdoor housing facilities
for potentially dangerous animals must be surrounded by a perimeter fence at least 8 feet in height. Additionally, it must
be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure. These requirements of a perimeter fence are necessary to help
ensure that unauthorized persons or animals cannot access the facility, to prevent physical contact between animals
inside the primary enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence, and to effectively function as a
secondary containment system in case of animal escape.
A system must be in place to ensure the perimeter fence surrounding the potentially dangerous animal enclosures is
constructed and maintained to achieve 8 feet in height or Administrator approval must be obtained for fences less than 8
feet.
Correct by 02/01/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
ALEXANDRA ANDRICOS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
